# Desalination in California

## Overview
Converting seawater or brackish water to freshwater.

## Operating Facilities

### Seawater Desalination
- Carlsbad (San Diego County): 50 MGD
- Largest in Western Hemisphere
- Online since 2015

### Brackish Water Desalination
- Multiple facilities statewide
- Lower energy than seawater
- Treats groundwater

## Regulatory Framework

### State Policy
- Ocean Plan provisions
- Intake and discharge requirements
- Environmental review

### Regional Permitting
- NPDES permits for discharge
- Coastal Development Permits
- Local land use approvals

## Environmental Considerations

### Intake Impacts
- Marine organism entrainment
- Impingement on screens
- Subsurface intake preferred

### Brine Discharge
- Concentrated salt water
- Dilution requirements
- Mixing zone limits
- Marine habitat protection

## Costs

### Capital Costs
- Very high ($1B+ for large facilities)
- Long permitting timeline

### Operating Costs
- Energy intensive
- $2,000+ per acre-foot typical
- Higher than most alternatives

## Role in Water Supply
- Drought-proof supply
- Diversification
- Climate adaptation
- Last resort in some views

## Key Resources
- [DWR Desalination Program](https://water.ca.gov/Work-With-Us/Grants-And-Loans/desalination-Grant-Program)
- [SWRCB Desalination Amendment](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/water_issues/programs/ocean/desalination/)
- [Water Resilience Portfolio - Diversified Supply](https://waterresilience.ca.gov/)

## Take Action
1. Learn more at [DWR Desalination Program](https://water.ca.gov/Work-With-Us/Grants-And-Loans/desalination-Grant-Program).
2. Review regulatory requirements at [SWRCB Desalination Amendment](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/water_issues/programs/ocean/desalination/).
3. Learn more at [Water Resilience Portfolio - Diversified Supply](https://waterresilience.ca.gov/).

# Groundwater Banking and Recharge

## What is Groundwater Banking?
Storing surface water underground during wet years for use during dry years.

## Recharge Methods

### Surface Spreading
- Water spread over permeable soils
- Infiltrates to aquifer
- Requires suitable geology
- Large land areas needed

### Injection Wells
- Direct injection into aquifer
- Requires treatment first
- More expensive
- Less land needed

### In-Lieu Recharge
- Use surface water instead of groundwater
- Allows aquifer to recover
- No infrastructure needed

## Major Banking Programs

### Kern Water Bank
- Largest in state
- 1.1 million AF capacity
- Multiple partners

### Arvin-Edison
- Pioneer in banking
- 350,000 AF capacity
- Water transfers

### Metropolitan Water District
- Several banking partnerships
- Southern California storage
- Drought reserve

## Regulatory Framework

### SGMA Connection
- GSPs must address recharge
- Sustainable yield determinations
- Avoid undesirable results

### Water Rights
- Storage rights needed
- Recovery rights
- Transfer considerations

## Benefits
- Drought resilience
- Aquifer recovery
- Supply reliability
- Climate adaptation

## Key Resources
- [DWR Groundwater Management](https://water.ca.gov/Programs/Groundwater-Management)
- [SGMA Groundwater Sustainability](https://water.ca.gov/Programs/Groundwater-Management/SGMA-Groundwater-Management)
- [SWRCB Groundwater Programs](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/water_issues/programs/groundwater/)
- [DWR Flood-MAR (Managed Aquifer Recharge)](https://water.ca.gov/Programs/All-Programs/Flood-MAR)

## Take Action

2. Review regulatory requirements at [SGMA Groundwater Sustainability](https://water.ca.gov/Programs/Groundwater-Management/SGMA-Groundwater-Management).

4. Learn more at [DWR Flood-MAR (Managed Aquifer Recharge)](https://water.ca.gov/Programs/All-Programs/Flood-MAR).

# California's Water Infrastructure

## State Water Project (SWP)

### Overview
- Largest state-built water system in US
- 700+ miles of aqueducts
- 34 storage facilities
- Serves 27 million people

### Key Facilities
- Oroville Dam and Lake
- California Aqueduct
- Edmonston Pumping Plant
- Coastal Branch

### Governance
- DWR operates
- State Water Contractors fund
- Long-term contracts

## Central Valley Project (CVP)

### Overview
- Federal project
- Bureau of Reclamation operates
- Primarily agricultural supply

### Key Facilities
- Shasta Dam and Lake
- Friant Dam and Millerton Lake
- Delta-Mendota Canal
- San Luis Reservoir (joint with SWP)

## Colorado River

### California Allocation
- 4.4 million acre-feet
- Priority rights
- Metropolitan, IID, others

### Key Infrastructure
- Colorado River Aqueduct
- Imperial Dam
- All-American Canal

## Local Projects

### Hetch Hetchy
- San Francisco supply
- O'Shaughnessy Dam

### Los Angeles Aqueduct
- Owens Valley supply
- Mulholland legacy

### Mokelumne Aqueduct
- East Bay MUD supply

# Agricultural Water Management

## California Agriculture and Water

### By the Numbers
- ~80% of developed water use
- 9 million irrigated acres
- $50+ billion annual production
- #1 agricultural state

## Regulatory Framework

### Agricultural Water Management Plans
- Required for large suppliers
- >25,000 irrigated acres
- Or >10,000 AF delivered
- Update every 5 years

### Efficient Water Management Practices
- Must implement all cost-effective
- Measurement and volumetric pricing
- Incentive pricing structures

## Irrigation Efficiency

### Methods
- Flood irrigation (least efficient)
- Sprinkler systems
- Drip/micro-irrigation (most efficient)
- Subsurface drip

### On-Farm Efficiency
- Soil moisture monitoring
- Evapotranspiration data
- Scheduling optimization
- Variable rate irrigation

## Water Quality Concerns

### Tailwater Runoff
- Sediment
- Fertilizers
- Pesticides
- Salts

### Groundwater Impacts
- Nitrate contamination
- Pesticide leaching
- Salt accumulation

## Programs and Incentives

### NRCS Programs
- EQIP (Environmental Quality Incentives)
- CSP (Conservation Stewardship)

### State Programs
- SWEEP grants
- CDFA programs

## Key Resources
- [Agricultural Water Management - DWR](https://water.ca.gov/Programs/Water-Use-And-Efficiency/Agricultural-Water-Use-Efficiency)
- [Irrigated Lands Regulatory Program](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/water_issues/programs/agriculture/)

## Take Action
1. Learn more at [Agricultural Water Management - DWR](https://water.ca.gov/Programs/Water-Use-And-Efficiency/Agricultural-Water-Use-Efficiency).
2. Review regulatory requirements at [Irrigated Lands Regulatory Program](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/water_issues/programs/agriculture/).
3. Contact your local Regional Water Quality Control Board for site-specific guidance.

# Statewide Water Planning

## California Water Plan (Update 2023)

### What It Is
- Strategic plan for water resources
- Updated every 5 years
- DWR prepares
- Not regulatory

### Key Elements
- Regional reports
- Resource management strategies
- Climate change adaptation
- Flood management

## Integrated Regional Water Management (IRWM)

### Purpose
- Regional collaboration
- Integrated planning
- Multi-benefit projects
- Funding eligibility

### IRWM Regions
- 48 regions statewide
- Regional water management groups
- IRWM plans

## Urban Water Management Plans

### Who Prepares
- Urban water suppliers
- >3,000 AF or 3,000 connections
- Update every 5 years

### Contents
- Supply and demand projections
- Reliability assessment
- Conservation programs
- Shortage contingency plans

## Groundwater Sustainability Plans (GSPs)

### SGMA Requirement
- Medium and high priority basins
- Groundwater Sustainability Agencies
- 20-year implementation

### Plan Elements
- Basin conditions
- Sustainable management criteria
- Monitoring programs
- Projects and management actions

## Climate Adaptation

### Water-Related Impacts
- More variable precipitation
- Earlier snowmelt
- Sea level rise
- More intense droughts and floods

## Key Resources
- [California Water Plan (Update 2023)](https://water.ca.gov/Programs/California-Water-Plan)
- [Water Resilience Portfolio](https://waterresilience.ca.gov/)
- [DWR Planning Programs](https://water.ca.gov/Programs)

2. Learn more at [Water Resilience Portfolio](https://waterresilience.ca.gov/).
3. Learn more at [DWR Planning Programs](https://water.ca.gov/Programs).

# Bay-Delta Water Issues

## What is the Delta?
- Sacramento-San Joaquin River Delta
- Hub of California water system
- Freshwater estuary
- Critical ecosystem

## Water Supply Role

### Export Facilities
- Banks Pumping Plant (SWP)
- Jones Pumping Plant (CVP)
- Supply 25+ million people
- Major agricultural supply

### Through-Delta Conveyance
- Water flows through Delta
- Tidal mixing
- Seawater intrusion risk

## Environmental Concerns

### Listed Species
- Delta smelt
- Salmon runs
- Other fish species
- Aquatic habitat

### Regulatory Requirements
- Biological opinions
- Incidental take permits
- Outflow requirements
- Export restrictions

## Delta Conveyance Project

### Proposed
- Single tunnel under Delta
- 6,000 cfs capacity
- Alternative to through-Delta

### Purpose
- Supply reliability
- Seismic resilience
- Operational flexibility

### Controversy
- Cost (billions)
- Environmental impacts
- Northern vs Southern CA
- Ecosystem effects

## Delta Stewardship Council

### Role
- Implement Delta Plan
- Coequal goals
- Appeal of covered actions
- Delta science

## Key Resources
- [Bay-Delta Program - SWRCB](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/waterrights/water_issues/programs/bay_delta/)
- [Delta Stewardship Council](https://deltacouncil.ca.gov/)
- [DWR Delta Conveyance](https://water.ca.gov/Programs/State-Water-Project/Delta-Conveyance)

2. Learn more at [Delta Stewardship Council](https://deltacouncil.ca.gov/).

# Harmful Algal Blooms (HABs)

## What are HABs?
- Overgrowth of algae or cyanobacteria
- Can produce toxins
- Freshwater and marine
- Climate-influenced

## Types in California

### Freshwater (Cyanobacteria)
- Blue-green algae
- Microcystis most common
- Lakes, reservoirs, rivers
- Anatoxin, microcystin toxins

### Marine
- Red tides
- Pseudo-nitzschia (domoic acid)
- Shellfish closures

## Health Risks

### Exposure Routes
- Swallowing water
- Skin contact
- Inhaling spray
- Eating contaminated fish/shellfish

### Symptoms
- Skin rash
- Eye irritation
- Nausea, vomiting
- Neurological effects (severe)
- Liver damage (severe)

### Who's Most at Risk
- Children
- Pets
- People with compromised immune systems

## Reporting and Monitoring

### California HAB Portal
- Incident reports
- Advisories
- Monitoring data

### Who to Contact
- Local health department
- Regional Water Board
- State Water Board HAB program

## When to Avoid Water

### Warning Signs
- Green, blue-green, or red color
- Surface scum
- Dead fish
- Posted warnings

### Precautions
- Don't swim, wade, or boat
- Keep pets out
- Don't drink or cook with
- Rinse if exposed

## Key Resources
- [SWAMP Freshwater HABs Program](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/water_issues/programs/swamp/freshwater_cyanobacteria.html)
- [HABs Portal](https://mywaterquality.ca.gov/habs/)
- [DDW HABs Program](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/drinking_water/programs/habs/)
- [OEHHA HABs Resources](https://oehha.ca.gov/habs/cyanobacteria-harmful-algal-blooms-habs-and-cyanotoxins-recreational-waters)

# Mercury in California Waters

## Sources of Mercury

### Historical Mining
- Gold rush legacy
- Mercury used in extraction
- Contaminated sediments
- Sierra Nevada watersheds

### Other Sources
- Atmospheric deposition
- Industrial sources
- Natural geological

## Mercury in Fish

### Bioaccumulation
- Mercury concentrates up food chain
- Highest in predator fish
- Bass, catfish, trout affected
- Some marine fish (tuna, shark)

### Health Effects
- Neurotoxin
- Developmental effects
- Especially harmful to fetuses/children
- Long-term exposure concern

## Fish Consumption Advisories

### OEHHA Advisories
- Lake-specific advisories
- Species-specific guidance
- Safe eating guidelines
- Sensitive populations

### Where to Find
- OEHHA website
- Fish consumption advisory database
- Signs at lakes/reservoirs

## Regulatory Programs

### TMDLs
- Mercury TMDLs for many water bodies
- San Francisco Bay
- Delta
- Cache Creek
- Others

### Mine Cleanup
- Abandoned mine lands program
- DTSC oversight
- Regional Board involvement

## Protecting Yourself

### Follow Advisories
- Check before fishing
- Follow consumption limits
- Vary fish species
- Sensitive populations extra careful

## Key Resources
- [Statewide Mercury Program](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/water_issues/programs/mercury/other_programs.html)

# Swimming Pool and Spa Regulations

## Public Pool Regulation

### Local Health Department
- Permit required
- Inspections
- Water quality monitoring
- Operator training

### State Standards
- Title 22 (pools and spas)
- Design standards
- Operation requirements
- Safety features

## Water Quality Requirements

### Disinfection
- Chlorine or bromine
- Minimum residual levels
- pH control
- Cyanuric acid limits

### Testing Frequency
- Multiple times daily
- Record keeping required
- Automated monitoring common

## Safety Requirements

### Physical Features
- Fencing and gates
- Drain covers (VGB Act)
- Depth markers
- No diving signs

### Lifeguarding
- When required
- Training requirements
- Rescue equipment

## Recreational Water Illness

### Common Pathogens
- Cryptosporidium
- Giardia
- E. coli
- Norovirus

### Prevention
- Don't swim when sick
- Shower before swimming
- Don't swallow pool water
- Take bathroom breaks

## Private Pools

### Less Regulated
- Building permits
- Fence requirements
- Owner responsibility
- No routine inspection

## Key Resources
- [CDPH Pool Safety and Regulations](https://www.cdph.ca.gov/Programs/CEH/DRSEM/Pages/EMB/RecreationalHealth/California-Swimming-Pool-Requirements.aspx)
- [CDC Recreational Water Health](https://www.cdc.gov/healthy-swimming/)

# Graywater Systems in California

## What is Graywater?
- Wastewater from laundry, showers, sinks
- NOT from toilets or kitchen sinks
- Can be reused for irrigation

## California Regulations

### Clothes Washer System (Simplest)
- No permit required if:
  - Single family dwelling
  - <250 gallons per day
  - Meets code requirements

### Simple Graywater Systems
- Building permit required
- Subsurface irrigation
- Specific design standards

### Complex Systems
- Larger or different configurations
- Full permit process
- Engineering review

## Design Requirements

### All Systems
- No surface ponding
- No runoff
- No spray irrigation
- No storage >24 hours
- Proper setbacks

### Permitted Systems
- System sizing
- Distribution design
- Surge capacity
- Maintenance access

## Benefits

### Water Savings
- 20-40 gallons per person per day
- Landscape irrigation supply
- Reduce outdoor water use

### Drought Resilience
- Less dependence on potable supply
- Keep landscapes alive

## Considerations

### What NOT to Put in Graywater
- Hazardous chemicals
- Strong detergents
- Chlorine bleach
- Boron (harmful to plants)

### Maintenance
- Clean filters
- Check distribution
- Avoid sodium buildup

## Key Resources
- [Graywater Reuse - SWRCB Overview](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/drinking_water/certlic/drinkingwater/onsite_nonpotable_reuse_regulations.html)
- [EPA Water Reuse Guidelines](https://www.epa.gov/waterreuse)

## Take Action
1. Learn more at [Graywater Reuse - SWRCB Overview](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/drinking_water/certlic/drinkingwater/onsite_nonpotable_reuse_regulations.html).
2. Learn more at [EPA Water Reuse Guidelines](https://www.epa.gov/waterreuse).
3. Contact your local Regional Water Quality Control Board for site-specific guidance.

# Rainwater Harvesting in California

## Legal Status

### California Law
- Legal to collect rainwater
- No permit typically required
- For on-site use
- Tax incentives available

## Collection Systems

### Rain Barrels
- Simple collection
- 50-100 gallon capacity
- Connect to downspout
- Gravity or small pump

### Cisterns
- Larger capacity
- Underground or above ground
- Requires more infrastructure
- Greater supply reliability

### Rainwater Harvesting Systems
- Whole-house systems possible
- Treatment for potable use
- Requires permitting
- Professional design

## Uses

### Non-Potable (Common)
- Landscape irrigation
- Toilet flushing
- Car washing
- Laundry

### Potable (With Treatment)
- Requires proper treatment
- Filtration and disinfection
- Local health approval
- Regular testing

## Design Considerations

### Collection Surface
- Roof area determines capacity
- Material affects water quality
- First flush diversion recommended

### Storage Sizing
- Based on rainfall patterns
- Intended use
- Budget

### Water Quality
- Debris screening
- First flush diversion
- Covered storage
- Treatment if needed

## Incentives

### Tax Credits
- California tax credits available
- Property tax exclusion possible

### Rebates
- Some utilities offer rebates
- Check local programs

- [DWR Water Use Efficiency](https://water.ca.gov/Programs/Water-Use-And-Efficiency)

# Secondary Drinking Water Standards

## What are Secondary Standards?
- Non-health based standards
- Aesthetic and cosmetic effects
- Taste, odor, appearance
- Not federally enforceable

## California Secondary MCLs

### Appearance
- Color: 15 units
- Turbidity: 5 NTU
- Foaming agents: 0.5 mg/L

### Taste/Odor
- Threshold odor number: 3
- Chloride: 500 mg/L
- Sulfate: 500 mg/L
- Total dissolved solids: 1,000 mg/L

### Other
- Iron: 0.3 mg/L
- Manganese: 0.05 mg/L
- Zinc: 5 mg/L
- Copper: 1 mg/L

## Effects of Exceeding

### High TDS
- Salty or bitter taste
- Scale buildup
- May indicate other issues

### High Iron/Manganese
- Staining (rust/black)
- Metallic taste
- Laundry staining

### High Hardness
- Not MCL, but causes:
- Scale in pipes and appliances
- Soap doesn't lather well
- Spotting on dishes

## Consumer Response

### Treatment Options
- Water softener (hardness)
- Iron/manganese filters
- Reverse osmosis (TDS)
- Activated carbon (taste/odor)

### Notification
- Systems may notify consumers
- Consumer Confidence Report includes
- Not a health violation

- [DDW Secondary Standards (PDF)](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/drinking_water/certlic/drinkingwater/documents/ddw_secondary_standards.pdf)

# Fluoride in Drinking Water

## California Fluoridation Policy

### State Law (1995)
- Requires fluoridation for large systems
- If outside funding available
- >10,000 service connections
- Many systems fluoridated

### MCL
- 2 mg/L (maximum allowed)
- To prevent dental fluorosis

### Optimal Level
- 0.7 mg/L recommended
- For dental health benefit
- HHS recommendation

## Health Effects

### Benefits
- Reduced tooth decay
- Community dental health
- Cost-effective public health

### Concerns (at high levels)
- Dental fluorosis (cosmetic)
- Skeletal fluorosis (very high levels)
- Controversy exists

## Natural Fluoride

### Occurrence
- Some groundwater naturally high
- Geological sources
- May exceed MCL naturally

### Treatment Needed
- If naturally exceeds MCL
- Defluoridation required
- Activated alumina
- Reverse osmosis

## Consumer Information

### Finding Your Level
- Consumer Confidence Report
- Contact water utility
- CDC's My Water's Fluoride

### Removing Fluoride
- Reverse osmosis removes
- Distillation removes
- Activated carbon does NOT remove

## Controversy

### Public Debate
- Some communities oppose
- Ballot measures
- Continuing discussion
- Both positions held strongly

## Key Resources
- [Fluoridation by Public Water Systems](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/drinking_water/certlic/drinkingwater/Fluoridation.html)

# Source Water Protection

## What is Source Water?
- Water before treatment
- Groundwater sources (wells)
- Surface water sources (rivers, lakes)
- Starting point for drinking water

## Source Water Assessments

### Required for PWS
- Identify source areas
- Inventory potential contamination sources
- Assess susceptibility
- Public reporting

### Assessment Elements
- Delineation of protection area
- Contaminant source inventory
- Vulnerability analysis

## Protection Strategies

### Wellhead Protection
- Protection zone around well
- Land use restrictions
- Monitoring wells
- Emergency response

### Surface Water Protection
- Watershed management
- Land use planning
- Agricultural BMPs
- Forest management

## Regulatory Tools

### Local Ordinances
- Wellhead protection ordinances
- Zoning restrictions

# Water System Cybersecurity

## Why Cybersecurity Matters

### Critical Infrastructure
- Water essential service
- Increasingly digital controls
- SCADA/ICS systems
- Potential targets

### Recent Incidents
- Oldsmar, Florida (2021)
- Increased attention to sector
- Federal focus on water cybersecurity

## Common Vulnerabilities

### Operational Technology
- Remote access
- Outdated systems
- Default passwords
- Unsecured connections

### IT Systems
- Billing systems
- Customer data
- Email/phishing
- Ransomware

## EPA Requirements

### America's Water Infrastructure Act
- Risk assessments required
- Emergency response plans
- Cybersecurity component
- Systems serving >3,300

## Best Practices

### Basic Steps
- Change default passwords
- Enable multi-factor authentication
- Regular updates and patches
- Network segmentation
- Employee training

### Advanced Measures
- Intrusion detection
- Access logging
- Incident response plan
- Regular assessments
